content.raw:
This seems odd to me.  So in the `LightRay.make_light_ray()` function, we can set a `data_filename` kwarg which effectively saves this LightRay object to an output file.  

1) Why does it need to *load* the data_filename in order to return the ray_ds?  Shouldn't the `_write_light_ray()` method be sufficient here to save the LightRay object?  Why return the dataset?

2) Wouldn't it be more consistent to have the LightRay class (or perhaps the actual returned ray) have a `save_as_dataset()` method to mimic the behavior of the other data objects?
content.html:
This seems odd to me. So in the LightRay.make_light_ray() function, we can set a data_filename kwarg which effectively saves this LightRay object to an output file.

1) Why does it need to load the data_filename in order to return the ray_ds? Shouldn't the _write_light_ray() method be sufficient here to save the LightRay object? Why return the dataset?

2) Wouldn't it be more consistent to have the LightRay class (or perhaps the actual returned ray) have a save_as_dataset() method to mimic the behavior of the other data objects?

content.raw: Perhaps this should be `save_as_dataset()` now?
content.html: Perhaps this should be save_as_dataset() now?

content.raw: Maybe instead of `yt_light_ray` change it to `LightRay`?
content.html: Maybe instead of yt_light_ray change it to LightRay?

content.raw: Interesting.  Perhaps at some point in the future, we should consolidate all of the logic that goes into making PlotWindow and VolumeRendering filenames into this so we just have a one-size-fits-all filename generator.  Nice work, here.
content.html: Interesting. Perhaps at some point in the future, we should consolidate all of the logic that goes into making PlotWindow and VolumeRendering filenames into this so we just have a one-size-fits-all filename generator. Nice work, here.

content.raw:
In general, I'm a big fan of this PR.  Great new functionality, good tests, and great docs.  Aside from the comments I left below in the code, I have one general comment.  When I try to use this functionality, the only clunky part.  Sometimes we have to run the `.all_data()` method on loaded datasets in order to get the exact same data object back as we started with, but this seems somewhat object dependent.  As an example,


```
#!python

ds = yt.load(filename)
sp = ds.sphere(0.5, (1, 'kpc'))
sp.save_as_dataset('sphere.h5')
sp_new = yt.load('sphere.h5')
sp_ad = sp_new.all_data()

print sp['density']
print sp_ad['density']

```

So in order to actually use our loaded sphere `sp_new` as we would our generated sphere `sp`, we have to create the `sp_ad` object instead of just loading up `sp_new` and going with it.  This seems to happen with any of the 1D, 2D, or 3D geometric data objects.  Couldn't we have the `.all_data()` call subsumed into the load command for these objects to avoid this extra step for the user?  Or is it kept explicit so that people could do further geometric slices on their dataset like saving a sphere dataset, then getting an intersecting geometric `region` from within it? e.g.


```
#!python

ds = yt.load()
sp = ds.sphere(0.5, (1, 'kpc'))
sp.save_as_dataset('sphere.h5')
sp_new = yt.load('sphere.h5')
sp_region = sp_new.box([0.5, 0.5, 0.5], [0.6, 0.6, 0.6])

```

There may be a good reason for the choices here.  I just wanted to remove a clunky user-side step if possible, because a naive user (like myself) might expect to get an object back from a load command *exactly* like what they saved.
content.html:
In general, I'm a big fan of this PR. Great new functionality, good tests, and great docs. Aside from the comments I left below in the code, I have one general comment. When I try to use this functionality, the only clunky part. Sometimes we have to run the .all_data() method on loaded datasets in order to get the exact same data object back as we started with, but this seems somewhat object dependent. As an example,

ds = yt.load(filename)
sp = ds.sphere(0.5, (1, 'kpc'))
sp.save_as_dataset('sphere.h5')
sp_new = yt.load('sphere.h5')
sp_ad = sp_new.all_data()

print sp['density']
print sp_ad['density']

So in order to actually use our loaded sphere sp_new as we would our generated sphere sp, we have to create the sp_ad object instead of just loading up sp_new and going with it. This seems to happen with any of the 1D, 2D, or 3D geometric data objects. Couldn't we have the .all_data() call subsumed into the load command for these objects to avoid this extra step for the user? Or is it kept explicit so that people could do further geometric slices on their dataset like saving a sphere dataset, then getting an intersecting geometric region from within it? e.g.

ds = yt.load()
sp = ds.sphere(0.5, (1, 'kpc'))
sp.save_as_dataset('sphere.h5')
sp_new = yt.load('sphere.h5')
sp_region = sp_new.box([0.5, 0.5, 0.5], [0.6, 0.6, 0.6])

There may be a good reason for the choices here. I just wanted to remove a clunky user-side step if possible, because a naive user (like myself) might expect to get an object back from a load command exactly like what they saved.

content.raw: Is it possible for the `save_as_dataset()` method and functions to default to saving *all* fields if the user does not specify a field?  The docstrings for these functions say: "If this is supplied, it is the list of fields to be exported into the data frame.  If not supplied, whatever fields presently exist will be used."  But I'm not sure what this means.  Only fields that have been indexed or created will be saved?  When I try to save something without specifying a field list, it just saves an empty data container.
content.html: Is it possible for the save_as_dataset() method and functions to default to saving all fields if the user does not specify a field? The docstrings for these functions say: "If this is supplied, it is the list of fields to be exported into the data frame. If not supplied, whatever fields presently exist will be used." But I'm not sure what this means. Only fields that have been indexed or created will be saved? When I try to save something without specifying a field list, it just saves an empty data container.

content.raw:
I've tried running this on a bunch of datasets from a bunch of different frontends.  In general, things behave the way you expect, except there are some problems with particle fields and with grid fields being diverted from their full fieldname tuple to ('grid', field).  I've put together a notebook demonstrating these issues here:

http://nbviewer.ipython.org/url/chummels.org/ytdata_testing.ipynb

Are we just reloading grid data as particle data because then we don't need the entire grid hierarchy?  Because it does limit the functionality we can use reloaded objects with when they get transmuted to particle datasets: no more plotting outside of ParticlePlots, etc.  But maybe that is the price to pay?
content.html:
I've tried running this on a bunch of datasets from a bunch of different frontends. In general, things behave the way you expect, except there are some problems with particle fields and with grid fields being diverted from their full fieldname tuple to ('grid', field). I've put together a notebook demonstrating these issues here:

http://nbviewer.ipython.org/url/chummels.org/ytdata_testing.ipynb

Are we just reloading grid data as particle data because then we don't need the entire grid hierarchy? Because it does limit the functionality we can use reloaded objects with when they get transmuted to particle datasets: no more plotting outside of ParticlePlots, etc. But maybe that is the price to pay?

content.html: Good suggestion, I'll do that.

content.raw: I don't think it makes much difference.  It's not a user-facing function.  This gets called when you provide a filename to ``make_light_ray``.  No one should be calling this directly.
content.html: I don't think it makes much difference. It's not a user-facing function. This gets called when you provide a filename to make_light_ray. No one should be calling this directly.

content.raw: The way it is now fits with the naming convention that has been used in the ytdata frontend of "yt_<data object name>", so I'd prefer to keep it that way.
content.html: The way it is now fits with the naming convention that has been used in the ytdata frontend of "yt_<data object name>", so I'd prefer to keep it that way.

content.raw: Yeah, I think that would be worth doing in the future.
content.html: Yeah, I think that would be worth doing in the future.

content.raw:
This was done to keep the functionality as similar as possible to how it used to be while also providing the benefits of the ytdata machinery.  You can see below that previously the ``all_data`` dictionary was returned such that the user had direct access to the field data.  Personally, I never use the ``LightRay`` machinery by capturing this return value, but I don't want to break backward compatibility just for myself.

As far as having a ``save_as_dataset`` function, I don't really see the benefit since this would be making what was once a one-step process (calling ``make_light_ray`` with a filename) and make it a two-step process (call ``make_light_ray``, then call ``save_as_dataset``).
content.html:
This was done to keep the functionality as similar as possible to how it used to be while also providing the benefits of the ytdata machinery. You can see below that previously the all_data dictionary was returned such that the user had direct access to the field data. Personally, I never use the LightRay machinery by capturing this return value, but I don't want to break backward compatibility just for myself.

As far as having a save_as_dataset function, I don't really see the benefit since this would be making what was once a one-step process (calling make_light_ray with a filename) and make it a two-step process (call make_light_ray, then call save_as_dataset).

content.raw: I kept it explicit to allow further geometric selection.  I would be open to adding something like a ``ds.data`` to be an automatically created data container that is the same type and configuration as the original data container.  How would you feel about that?
content.html: I kept it explicit to allow further geometric selection. I would be open to adding something like a ds.data to be an automatically created data container that is the same type and configuration as the original data container. How would you feel about that?

content.raw: It was meant to say that fields that have already been indexed would be saved, but I would be open to making it save all fields in the ``field_list`` since there is currently no easy way to do that.
content.html: It was meant to say that fields that have already been indexed would be saved, but I would be open to making it save all fields in the field_list since there is currently no easy way to do that.

content.raw:
Most of this behavior is intentional and performs as laid out in the original YTEP.

Data container datasets have to be reloaded as particle data because because the grid layout is lost when you query grid data from a geometric data container.  The only way to do this and preserve the grid nature of the data would be to save all grid patches and masks for all grids at least partially contained within the bounds of the data container.  This would significantly bloat the size of the saved dataset and would also be a huge amount of work to implement.  However, when grid data is saved, we also save the dx, dy, and dz field values, so in theory, regular projections and slices could be produced from these datasets.  I think this could be done, but I would prefer if this were saved for future work as I don't know exactly what it would take to implement and I don't know how much more time I have to pour into this project.

As for the renaming of the grid data to be ("grid", <field_name>), this was necessary to distinguish between grid and particle fields in the reloaded dataset.  Furthermore, if the original field types are kept, then we have a situation where the "gas" fields mainly live in the "gas" group, but their positions and cell sizes live in the "index" group.  This would end up creating a giant mess within the reloaded dataset as I would have to create some sort of map of field data to their corresponding cell positions.  As a compromise, I would be willing to re-alias "grid" fields to "gas" so they can still be accessed using the original name.

As for the final error you show in the ipython notebook regarding datasets that are just particles, that seems like a genuine bug and I will look into it.
content.html:
Most of this behavior is intentional and performs as laid out in the original YTEP.

Data container datasets have to be reloaded as particle data because because the grid layout is lost when you query grid data from a geometric data container. The only way to do this and preserve the grid nature of the data would be to save all grid patches and masks for all grids at least partially contained within the bounds of the data container. This would significantly bloat the size of the saved dataset and would also be a huge amount of work to implement. However, when grid data is saved, we also save the dx, dy, and dz field values, so in theory, regular projections and slices could be produced from these datasets. I think this could be done, but I would prefer if this were saved for future work as I don't know exactly what it would take to implement and I don't know how much more time I have to pour into this project.

As for the renaming of the grid data to be ("grid", <field_name>), this was necessary to distinguish between grid and particle fields in the reloaded dataset. Furthermore, if the original field types are kept, then we have a situation where the "gas" fields mainly live in the "gas" group, but their positions and cell sizes live in the "index" group. This would end up creating a giant mess within the reloaded dataset as I would have to create some sort of map of field data to their corresponding cell positions. As a compromise, I would be willing to re-alias "grid" fields to "gas" so they can still be accessed using the original name.

As for the final error you show in the ipython notebook regarding datasets that are just particles, that seems like a genuine bug and I will look into it.

content.raw: The last issue was a silly bug where I had left in a variable that I wasn't even using.  Particle-only datasets work just fine now.
content.html: The last issue was a silly bug where I had left in a variable that I wasn't even using. Particle-only datasets work just fine now.

content.raw: I take back what I said here.  Saving all the fields in the field_list when no argument is given created a whole new set of problems.  If we saved the fields on the field_list, these would be the original frontend-specific field names and not the general aliased names.  For example, with enzo, we would be saving ("Enzo", "Density") and not ("gas", "density").  Therefore, to be usable as ("gas", "density") after reloading, we would have to know all the possible aliases from all frontends for every field.  This would be a nightmare, so I have fixed up the docstring so that it more clearly states that one will only get the fields that have been queried in the case where a list of field has not been given.
content.html: I take back what I said here. Saving all the fields in the field_list when no argument is given created a whole new set of problems. If we saved the fields on the field_list, these would be the original frontend-specific field names and not the general aliased names. For example, with enzo, we would be saving ("Enzo", "Density") and not ("gas", "density"). Therefore, to be usable as ("gas", "density") after reloading, we would have to know all the possible aliases from all frontends for every field. This would be a nightmare, so I have fixed up the docstring so that it more clearly states that one will only get the fields that have been queried in the case where a list of field has not been given.

content.raw:
Update: I have responded to @chummels's comments and made the following changes:

* all "grid" type fields are now aliased to "gas"

* fixed the bug where fields could not be accessed for particle-only datasets

* clarified docstrings to make it clear that only previously queried fields will be saved if no field list is given (with explanation above of why we can't simply save all fields)

* added link in docs to specific section on remaking plots from saved datasets
content.html:
Update: I have responded to chummels's comments and made the following changes:

  • all "grid" type fields are now aliased to "gas"

  • fixed the bug where fields could not be accessed for particle-only datasets

  • clarified docstrings to make it clear that only previously queried fields will be saved if no field list is given (with explanation above of why we can't simply save all fields)

  • added link in docs to specific section on remaking plots from saved datasets

content.raw:
Oh, so you mean, that if you do this:


```
#!python

ds = yt.load(filename)
sp = ds.sphere(0.5, (1, 'kpc'))
sp.save_as_dataset('sphere.h5')
ds2 = yt.load('sphere.h5')
sp2 = ds2.data
```

Then both `sp` and `sp2` would be sphere objects instead of `sp` being a sphere, and `sp2` being a region object (which would happen if we just did `sp2 = ds2.all_data()`)?  I'd be in favor of this, but I guess it isn't a huge deal.
content.html:
Oh, so you mean, that if you do this:

ds = yt.load(filename)
sp = ds.sphere(0.5, (1, 'kpc'))
sp.save_as_dataset('sphere.h5')
ds2 = yt.load('sphere.h5')
sp2 = ds2.data

Then both sp and sp2 would be sphere objects instead of sp being a sphere, and sp2 being a region object (which would happen if we just did sp2 = ds2.all_data())? I'd be in favor of this, but I guess it isn't a huge deal.

content.raw:
Wouldn't it be possible to just save the name of the frontend in the metadata of the h5 output file, and when one loads the h5 file as a new dataset to just look at what aliases are relevant for that frontend?

This could be future work if you don't want to handle it right now, but I think this could be beneficial for the user who just wants to keep all the fields without explicltly listing them in the `save_as_output()` call.
content.html:
Wouldn't it be possible to just save the name of the frontend in the metadata of the h5 output file, and when one loads the h5 file as a new dataset to just look at what aliases are relevant for that frontend?

This could be future work if you don't want to handle it right now, but I think this could be beneficial for the user who just wants to keep all the fields without explicltly listing them in the save_as_output() call.

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw:
OK, yeah, I don't want you to have to do a bunch of extra work to get the hierarchy included in the outputs for now.  Particles are fine, unless @ngoldbaum can figure out how to make the slices/projections to work easily.

On the second point about ("grid", <field name>) versus ("gas", <field name>)--I'm not sure I fully understand the difficulty here.  You want to have all of the grid-based fields (which are now particle fields) listed in the "grid" field tuple, and you're concerned that by keeping the original "gas" field tuple will be confusing because then the positions and cell sizes will live in the "index" field group.  

But isn't this how all of the original grid-based frontends work?  We have a bunch of grid-based fields, and their grid positions and cell sizes are already in the `index` field group.  Shouldn't all of the grid-based fields in the ytdata file have the same `("index", 'x')`, `('index', 'y')`, and `('index', 'z')` values so there wouldn't really need to be an explicit mapping per field?  Or is it because now all of the particle fields *and* the grid *fields* are particle fields in the ytdata file, so one doesn't know a priori which ones map to `particle_position_x` and which ones map to `('index', 'x')`? Or maybe I'm missing something here.
content.html:
OK, yeah, I don't want you to have to do a bunch of extra work to get the hierarchy included in the outputs for now. Particles are fine, unless Nathan Goldbaum can figure out how to make the slices/projections to work easily.

On the second point about ("grid", <field name>) versus ("gas", <field name>)--I'm not sure I fully understand the difficulty here. You want to have all of the grid-based fields (which are now particle fields) listed in the "grid" field tuple, and you're concerned that by keeping the original "gas" field tuple will be confusing because then the positions and cell sizes will live in the "index" field group.

But isn't this how all of the original grid-based frontends work? We have a bunch of grid-based fields, and their grid positions and cell sizes are already in the index field group. Shouldn't all of the grid-based fields in the ytdata file have the same ("index", 'x'), ('index', 'y'), and ('index', 'z') values so there wouldn't really need to be an explicit mapping per field? Or is it because now all of the particle fields and the grid fields are particle fields in the ytdata file, so one doesn't know a priori which ones map to particle_position_x and which ones map to ('index', 'x')? Or maybe I'm missing something here.

content.raw: I can see an instance where someone has made the LightRay and didn't put a filename in their `make_light_ray` call to save it and still wants to save it.  Since it's effectively doing exactly what all of the other `save_as_dataset()` methods and functions are doing for all of the other data object classes, would it be possible to just change this function name to be `save_as_dataset()` for consistency?
content.html: I can see an instance where someone has made the LightRay and didn't put a filename in their make_light_ray call to save it and still wants to save it. Since it's effectively doing exactly what all of the other save_as_dataset() methods and functions are doing for all of the other data object classes, would it be possible to just change this function name to be save_as_dataset() for consistency?

My jupyter notebook returns the same behavior for the top half as it did before the change, and the "gas" fields don't appear in the derived_field_list of the reloaded ytdata dataset.
content.html: I have tested the update, and while the bug regarding particle-only datasets has been fixed. The aliasing of "gas" fields to "grid" fields didn't seem to have any effect. My jupyter notebook returns the same behavior for the top half as it did before the change, and the "gas" fields don't appear in the derived_field_list of the reloaded ytdata dataset.

content.raw: Yes, you could save the name of the frontend and then on re-load, look up its field_info_container and apply all the aliases in there.  I'm sure this could be worked out, but I would very much like this to be considered something for the future as I am all but out of gas for this PR.
content.html: Yes, you could save the name of the frontend and then on re-load, look up its field_info_container and apply all the aliases in there. I'm sure this could be worked out, but I would very much like this to be considered something for the future as I am all but out of gas for this PR.

content.raw:
The ``("index", ...)`` fields are created by yt based on the grid corners, but in the ytdata case, these positions have to be written to disk.  You want the position fields to be saved to the same group in the hdf5 file so that when you read them back in, it is easy to figure out which position fields are associated with fields.  Right now, the frontend figures out which field types exist by checking what groups there are in the hdf5 file.  If we kept the names as is, there would be an "index" group with just positions and no fields and also a "gas" group with fields but no corresponding positions.  One would have to know that "gas" and "index" are linked in this way and add a bunch of hard-coded checking to make sure that we end up with the field types we want and none that we don't.  This would make the code very ugly and would also make it more difficult should we ever decide to move away from "gas" as the default grid field type.

Maybe I'm wrong, but by aliasing all the "grid" fields back to "gas", the user should see no change in behavior.  I will make sure this works, but any more than that I am not going to be able to do.
content.html:
The ("index", ...) fields are created by yt based on the grid corners, but in the ytdata case, these positions have to be written to disk. You want the position fields to be saved to the same group in the hdf5 file so that when you read them back in, it is easy to figure out which position fields are associated with fields. Right now, the frontend figures out which field types exist by checking what groups there are in the hdf5 file. If we kept the names as is, there would be an "index" group with just positions and no fields and also a "gas" group with fields but no corresponding positions. One would have to know that "gas" and "index" are linked in this way and add a bunch of hard-coded checking to make sure that we end up with the field types we want and none that we don't. This would make the code very ugly and would also make it more difficult should we ever decide to move away from "gas" as the default grid field type.

Maybe I'm wrong, but by aliasing all the "grid" fields back to "gas", the user should see no change in behavior. I will make sure this works, but any more than that I am not going to be able to do.

content.raw: It turns out I had only fixed it for grid datasets and not particle datasets.  It's now fixed for both and your notebook should now work.
content.html: It turns out I had only fixed it for grid datasets and not particle datasets. It's now fixed for both and your notebook should now work.

content.raw: One quick question: what do the `("index", ...) fields actually represent in the ytdata datasets then?  If we're just using the `("grid", "x")`, `("grid", "y")`, `("grid", "z")` fields for positions of the `("grid", ...)`spatial fields, then what do the `("index", "x")`, `("index", "y")`, `("index", "z")` do?
content.html: One quick question: what do the ("index", ...) fields actually represent in the ytdata datasets then? If we're just using the("grid", "x"),("grid", "y"),("grid", "z")fields for positions of the("grid", ...)spatial fields, then what do the("index", "x"),("index", "y"),("index", "z")` do?

content.raw: The ("grid", "x") fields are the true positions of the original grid cells that we're now treating as particles.  The ("index", "x") fields are the centers of the cells of the oct-tree that gets created to organize the particle data.  These would be the cells used for creating deposited fields.
content.html: The ("grid", "x") fields are the true positions of the original grid cells that we're now treating as particles. The ("index", "x") fields are the centers of the cells of the oct-tree that gets created to organize the particle data. These would be the cells used for creating deposited fields.

content.raw: That's mostly making sure print is used like a function. You can do `print (output)` to make it simultaneously valid python2 and python3 syntax. content.html: That's mostly making sure print is used like a function. You can do print (output) to make it simultaneously valid python2 and python3 syntax. If you use dict.keys() or dict.items(), you also probably want to make sure that the output is explicitly a list too. Of course the easiest way to check is to run the examples under python3.4.

content.raw:
First, this is really great, @brittonsmith! The Python 3 issues should be easy to work out. 

So, my biggest issue with this is that a lot of the derived quantities are broken. For example, `total_mass` throws an error:

```python
import yt
ds = yt.load("GasSloshing/sloshing_nomag2_hdf5_plt_cnt_0100")
sp = ds.sphere("c", (500.,"kpc"))
sp.save_as_dataset(fields=["density","kT"])
ds2 = yt.load("sloshing_nomag2_hdf5_plt_cnt_0100_sphere.h5")
sp2 = ds2.all_data()
sp2.quantities.total_mass()
```
The traceback is too long to post in the comment:

http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5996/

Some of the others have other issues as well. 

I know that Britton has spent a lot of time on this, and I don't want to make more work for him, but unfortunately I personally feel like derived quantities are a blocker to getting this in. If you load a data object back in as a dataset, you should be able to run the same quantities on it that you had when you created it and get the same answer. 

I'm happy to help chip in and figure this out.
content.html:
First, this is really great, Britton Smith! The Python 3 issues should be easy to work out.

So, my biggest issue with this is that a lot of the derived quantities are broken. For example, total_mass throws an error:

import yt
ds = yt.load("GasSloshing/sloshing_nomag2_hdf5_plt_cnt_0100")
sp = ds.sphere("c", (500.,"kpc"))
sp.save_as_dataset(fields=["density","kT"])
ds2 = yt.load("sloshing_nomag2_hdf5_plt_cnt_0100_sphere.h5")
sp2 = ds2.all_data()
sp2.quantities.total_mass()

The traceback is too long to post in the comment:

http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5996/

Some of the others have other issues as well.

I know that Britton has spent a lot of time on this, and I don't want to make more work for him, but unfortunately I personally feel like derived quantities are a blocker to getting this in. If you load a data object back in as a dataset, you should be able to run the same quantities on it that you had when you created it and get the same answer.

I'm happy to help chip in and figure this out.

content.raw: I should clarify that these issues crop up on Python 2 as well.
content.html: I should clarify that these issues crop up on Python 2 as well.

content.raw:
You're only saving the `density` and `kT` fields to the dataset, so it isn't expected that the derived quantity for `total_mass` will work, since total mass requires the `cell_mass` field and the particle `mass` fields.  If you save all of the fields, it might work, though.

The main limitation to keep in mind is that grid fields get reloaded as particle-based fields, and only the fields that you explicitly saved will be reloaded, so derived quantities will only work that deal with the fields that you saved to the external dataset.
content.html:
You're only saving the density and kT fields to the dataset, so it isn't expected that the derived quantity for total_mass will work, since total mass requires the cell_mass field and the particle mass fields. If you save all of the fields, it might work, though.

The main limitation to keep in mind is that grid fields get reloaded as particle-based fields, and only the fields that you explicitly saved will be reloaded, so derived quantities will only work that deal with the fields that you saved to the external dataset.

content.raw: In this specific case I don't agree--cell_mass is derived from density and cell_volume, both of which are in fact accessible to the new dataset. If you read the traceback you'll see this. It should work for this case, we just need to figure out how. The other issues which I still need to report exist even if all of the correct fields are present.
content.html: In this specific case I don't agree--cell_mass is derived from density and cell_volume, both of which are in fact accessible to the new dataset. If you read the traceback you'll see this. It should work for this case, we just need to figure out how. The other issues which I still need to report exist even if all of the correct fields are present.

content.raw: But the density field is being re-loaded as a particle field, not a grid-based field.  So in this case, the cell_mass field won't be calculated correctly because the loaded ytdata dataset has density, x,y,z of only particles.  I think that is the main holdup here, that we load grid-based fields back as particle-based fields.  But in order to do grid-based as grid-based, we have to save a lot more information that is going to bloat the hdf5 output file and take a lot more work to implement.  But Britton might hav emore to say on this.
content.html: But the density field is being re-loaded as a particle field, not a grid-based field. So in this case, the cell_mass field won't be calculated correctly because the loaded ytdata dataset has density, x,y,z of only particles. I think that is the main holdup here, that we load grid-based fields back as particle-based fields. But in order to do grid-based as grid-based, we have to save a lot more information that is going to bloat the hdf5 output file and take a lot more work to implement. But Britton might hav emore to say on this.

content.raw: I've checked--dx, dy, and dz are already present, and have the correct shape. The issue is that cell_volume does not have the right shape (again, check the traceback). I understand what you mean--but that doesn't seem to be the problem here. The three fields we need are already there--no need to add any others. We just need to figure out why the shape is wrong. I'm happy to fix it myself.
content.html: I've checked--dx, dy, and dz are already present, and have the correct shape. The issue is that cell_volume does not have the right shape (again, check the traceback). I understand what you mean--but that doesn't seem to be the problem here. The three fields we need are already there--no need to add any others. We just need to figure out why the shape is wrong. I'm happy to fix it myself.

content.raw: We discussed this in a previous comment on this PR.  The "index" fields are identified as grid corners, whereas the `density` is based on particle positions.  Check out the discussion starting with "I've tried running this on a bunch of datasets from a bunch of different frontends."
content.html: We discussed this in a previous comment on this PR. The "index" fields are identified as grid corners, whereas the density is based on particle positions. Check out the discussion starting with "I've tried running this on a bunch of datasets from a bunch of different frontends."

content.raw:
I read all of the comments--I feel like we are talking past each other a bit. I am pretty sure I understand what you are getting at. 

However, I just tried this on the `sp2` container (which came from the `ytdata` dataset) defined in my script above:

```python
(sp2["density"]*sp2["dx"]*sp2["dy"]*sp2["dz"]).sum()
```

which gave the correct answer. This demonstrates that we have all of this information in the container as-is, so I still don't see why we can't figure out why `cell_volume` isn't being calculated correctly.
content.html:
I read all of the comments--I feel like we are talking past each other a bit. I am pretty sure I understand what you are getting at.

However, I just tried this on the sp2 container (which came from the ytdata dataset) defined in my script above:

(sp2["density"]*sp2["dx"]*sp2["dy"]*sp2["dz"]).sum()

which gave the correct answer. This demonstrates that we have all of this information in the container as-is, so I still don't see why we can't figure out why cell_volume isn't being calculated correctly.

content.raw:
One other wrinkle: for example, the field `("index","dx")` is calculated by the geometry (and has a different shape from the density) but the file itself appears to have `dx`, etc. inside it, copied over from the dataset, and this field `("grid","dx")` is the one that is being grabbed by `sp2[]`. 

So we in fact do have all that we need in the file already--we just need to make sure we use it correctly. Maybe for ytdata datasets we should define `cell_volume` based on the deltas in the dataset instead of having the coordinate handler do it.
content.html:
One other wrinkle: for example, the field ("index","dx") is calculated by the geometry (and has a different shape from the density) but the file itself appears to have dx, etc. inside it, copied over from the dataset, and this field ("grid","dx") is the one that is being grabbed by sp2[].

So we in fact do have all that we need in the file already--we just need to make sure we use it correctly. Maybe for ytdata datasets we should define cell_volume based on the deltas in the dataset instead of having the coordinate handler do it.

content.raw:
The `"dx"`, `"dy"`, `"dz"` (or specifically the `("grid", "dx")`) fields are the sizes of the original cells that were saved, whereas the `("index", "dx")` fields are being generated by the geometry handler and are the sizes of the oct cells used to manage the reloaded data, which is being treated as particle data.  That's why we have the two different fields.

The problem now is that `"cell_mass"` is defined using the `("index", "cell_volume")` field, which is defined as the product of the `("index", "dx")` fields.  We can add a special definition of a `"cell_volume"` field to this frontend to use the `("grid", "dx")` fields, but then there's the definition of the `"cell_mass"` field.  Do we keep adding frontend-specific field definitions or do we redefine existing fields?
content.html:
The "dx", "dy", "dz" (or specifically the ("grid", "dx")) fields are the sizes of the original cells that were saved, whereas the ("index", "dx") fields are being generated by the geometry handler and are the sizes of the oct cells used to manage the reloaded data, which is being treated as particle data. That's why we have the two different fields.

The problem now is that "cell_mass" is defined using the ("index", "cell_volume") field, which is defined as the product of the ("index", "dx") fields. We can add a special definition of a "cell_volume" field to this frontend to use the ("grid", "dx") fields, but then there's the definition of the "cell_mass" field. Do we keep adding frontend-specific field definitions or do we redefine existing fields?

content.raw:
I think perhaps what may be in order is a special coordinate handler for these datasets, which defines the coordinate info from what is in the file.

I don't want to be a pain, but I suspect that derived quantities are one of those things that our users expect to "just work", provided that the required fields are in the dataset. I think getting a working cell_volume is all that is required here. 

Now that I've caused such a fuss, I must sheepishly admit that I cannot make the PR hangout today, but I want to work on fixing the py3 issues and have a look at derived quantities later this afternoon.
content.html:
I think perhaps what may be in order is a special coordinate handler for these datasets, which defines the coordinate info from what is in the file.

I don't want to be a pain, but I suspect that derived quantities are one of those things that our users expect to "just work", provided that the required fields are in the dataset. I think getting a working cell_volume is all that is required here.

Now that I've caused such a fuss, I must sheepishly admit that I cannot make the PR hangout today, but I want to work on fixing the py3 issues and have a look at derived quantities later this afternoon.

content.raw:
Hi all -- I think this is ready to go in.  I experimented with things and I think @brittonsmith's solution will work for now for the issues @jzuhone raised.

I have an alternate approach that I am working on that is *not* ready, and which will require breaking down a bit of the barrier between the particle and fluid fields.  That is something that *should* happen, but I am not yet sure how to fully implement it, and it would be of a bigger magnitude.  If this is close enough to working, it should go in.
content.html:
Hi all -- I think this is ready to go in. I experimented with things and I think Britton Smith's solution will work for now for the issues John ZuHone raised.

I have an alternate approach that I am working on that is not ready, and which will require breaking down a bit of the barrier between the particle and fluid fields. That is something that should happen, but I am not yet sure how to fully implement it, and it would be of a bigger magnitude. If this is close enough to working, it should go in.

content.raw: I'll poke around with this later today (or at the latest, tomorrow) and then approve and merge.
content.html: I'll poke around with this later today (or at the latest, tomorrow) and then approve and merge.

description:
This PR adds a frontend to allow for nearly all data produced by yt to be saved as a reloadable dataset.  This includes:

* geometric data containers (sphere, region, disk, all_data, etc)
* grid data containers (covering_grid, arbitrary_grid, fixed_resolution_buffer)
* spatial plots (projections, slices)
* profiles
* generic array data

In the case of projections, slices, and profiles, the reloaded datasets can be given to ``ProjectionPlot``, ``SlicePlot``, ``ProfilePlot``, and ``PhasePlot`` to regenerate images.

[This notebook](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/url/www.roe.ac.uk/~brs/notebooks/ytdata.ipynb) gives examples of all of the above functionality.

All functionality is complete with tests and narrative docs.
